comment.author: 27398485@N08
comment._content: This rock cut temple was built (one of two side by side) by Ramses II, 19th dynasty, (1314-1224 B.C.) honoring the Gods Amon Re (Amun Re) Re Horakhte, near Aswan. In 1966 to 1968, they were cut away from the rock face in large pieces, moved to higher ground and reassembled, to save them from the rising water level, due to the Aswan Dam. The facade statues are 67 feet tall.

comment.author: 93082027@N00
comment._content: I believe UNESCO had something to do with them being saved. It's unbelievable that these weren't part of the original plan to move when the dam was built, but perhaps it was just a case of the water level being underestimated.

comment.author: 35226125@N08
comment._content: was this  taken before or after the restoration?
